results.title: The Lost soldier
results.creator_credit: Ken Saunders, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Saunders reflects on the silence reverie of his father, a returned soldier. He never spoke about the war and, when Ken tried to broach the subject, told Ken to let sleeping dogs lie. This left Ken wondering about the demons that his dad confronts alone and the war that took his brother Harry. Spurred by the belief that all warriors need to come home, Ken initiates his own research to find out all he can about Harry and, eventually, return his brother’s spirit home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Saunders, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Letters from Java
results.brief_description: Eric Peters only knew his dad through what records were left behind. They were mostly letters that came through the censors at a POW camp in Burma and old photos. He reflects on the sadness of not knowing his dad and the importance of bringing his spirit home to rest.

results.title: Compression
results.brief_description: Ricky Morris is the 21st member of his family to see active service for Australia. He is proud to be part of the fighting Gunditjmarra people. His story looks at the invisible pressures modern soldiers constantly face and his realisation that this was shared by his family waiting for him at home.

results.title: Bringing his spirit home
results.creator_credit: Dot Peters, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dot Peters’ father was 39 when he joined World War II. He fought in the Middle East and was later captured in Java and sent to a Prisoner of War camp in Japan. He died there, leaving a grieving family wondering what he went through. Simultaneously, they witnessed the injustices inflicted on fellow Indigenous servicemen who had experienced equality overseas, only to find it stripped away on their return. This inspired Dot to dedicate the rest of her life to fighting for Indigenous rights, eventually collaborating with the Shrine of Remembrance to recognise the contribution made by Indigenous people during the war. This fight has helped her to bring her father’s spirit home, to bestow upon his memory a sense of belonging, recognition and honour.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dot Peters, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Back to being black
results.brief_description: John Lovett reflects on the injustices experienced by his father and so many other indigenous war veterans who were not recognised or afforded the same benefits as their white mates when they returned from service.

results.title: Why two numbers
results.creator_credit: Jayne Mooney, Noel O'Brien, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The O’Brien family have served in the army since the 1800s. Noel O’Brien, himself a member of the service, delves into the military history of his family and, in particular, of his father. Francis Charles O’Brien had two regimental numbers to his name and Noel wanted to find out the reason. As a result, he discovers something of his father’s personality, a larrikin who got himself into trouble, but was courageous enough to always be there for his mates.

results.title: When war came to Australia
results.creator_credit: Bill Hosking, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A recent visit to Darwin with his son reminded Bill Hosking of the time that war came to Australia. As one of the men who defended Darwin during that time, he was instructed to keep the details of the attack secret. In 1942, Bill Hosking joined up and was shipped up to train in the Northern Territory. It was during this time that the air raids on Darwin took place. Bill shares his experiences because he believes that not many people today know the story of how Australia came under attack.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Hosking, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: When the priest came
results.creator_credit: Brianna Smith, Paul Penno, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Paul was taught from an early age to fear the spread of communism. Then the opportunity came to fight it when he was conscripted in the army during the Vietnam war. Initially, it was a lark travelling around Vietnam, visiting villages, but things got serious soon enough. A priest was flown in and soldiers either clung on to their beliefs, or questioned them. Paul’s involvement in the war put him at odds with his father but, having experienced war first-hand, Paul begins to understand why his father felt the way he did.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brianna Smith, Paul Penno, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Paul was taught from an early age to fear the spread of communism. Then the opportunity came to fight it when he was conscripted in the army during the Vietnam war. Initially, it was a lark travelling around Vietnam, visiting villages, but things got serious soon enough. A priest was flown in and soldiers either clung on to their beliefs, or questioned them. Paul’s involvement in the war put him at odds with his father but, having experienced war first-hand, Paul begins to understand why his father felt the way he did.

results.title: When a job becomes a passion
results.creator_credit: John Balsillie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Major John Balsillie was first posted to Malaya during World War II, he became interested in World War II research and military history. It soon developed into a passion and he shipped off over 20 crates of war relics to the Australian War Memorial in Canberra. He talks of his subsequent visits during the 1960s and the second time he served, in Vietnam. This interest became a lifelong passion for John, for which he was recently awarded an MBE for services to the Australian War Memorial. John sees his role as providing a record of the brave soldiers who gave their lives for Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Balsillie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
